p: Whenever metagenomics is used for the detection of pathogens, it is crucial to use reliable bioinformatic tools and specialized databases that would help decide whether discovered microorganisms indeed have caused the infection or act merely as artifacts. Such processing normally demands lots of computing power and knowledge and skills in bioinformatics. Typically, data analysis mainly involves comparing obtained reads with reference genomes. Quite a few algorithms have been developed for this purpose [ 153], with BLAST being the most widely used [ 154]. However, BLAST works slowly for the analysis of NGS data [ 155], and processing times can take several days, or even weeks, especially when calculations are performed for amino acids. Other often-used programs are Bowtie [ 156] and BWA (Burrows-Wheeler Aligner) [ 157], which are usually employed as filtration tools, and DIAMOND as an alternative to BLAST [ 158].
